body.p:
Of the fat of heaven may handfulls, blessings
and life etc. the accomplished Isaac Leeser,

Indirectly, through God's friend and mine,
the learned, wise, accomplished Mister Niumburg
of the Congregation Kenesseth Israel in this city,
about the great commotion caused between
your honorable self and the rabbi of the cong-
regation of Charleston. The basis of the dis-
pute is the meaning of the words "I will
be what I will be" in the Biblical portion
of Exodus 3:14, and I decided that I too
ought to look into, and apply my limited
mind to the meaning of these words according
to my small comprehension and in so far
as God grants me the power to do so, and then
present my results before you. Since, how-
ever my knowledge and worth do not seem to fit
for me for it, and since the meaning of these
words is very profound and it is hard to get
it through superficial translation, I decided
to support my self own ideas with by the words of our

sages, "Sometimes a pearl is found in very
poor wrappings." And so I begin—

First I must point out several difficulties
in that very verse (14)

1-Why is the words "and he said" used twice in the
same verse?

2-Why is the expression, "Thus shalt thou say" used
after the second "and he said"? If this is an
answer to a question by Moses, the Torah
might have said briefly, "And God said
to Moses, 'thus shall you say to the Children of
Israel, I will be that I will be sent me to
you'"

3-Why is it said repeated in the following verse, "Thus
shalt thou say to the Children of Israel," and
why does God remind him in this verse and
not before that he Moses is to say to Israel
"God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob?
Now for the answer—

The great sight which Moses saw in the bush
when God came to him alone, was the first vision
at that time Moses did not know the nature of
God, nor his Name, nor his attributes. That
is why Moses asked the name, i.e. "If Israel
want to know your name by which they might

know and believe in you that you are their
redeemer, if they ask me such a question
what shall I tell them?" God's answer them
was "I will be that I will be" i. e. "You
need not know or announce my name,
for I need no announcement of my name
except through my deeds. For I am ever-
lasting, and my name is already well
known in the world. Moreover, they may
not ask you about this. But only if
by chance they do ask you, say to them
'I will be sent me to you', i. e. say
to them, "the Everlasting sent me to you!"
The meaning of the second "I will be" is
"say to them, 'I will be a father to them and
a redeemer from Pharoah'," And if they
are not satisfied even with this, the second
"Thus shalt thou say" is used i.e. "Say unto
them, that I shall remain, and realize for
them that which I promised to Abraham,
Isaac and Jacob, namely to redeem them
and bring them forth with great wealth,
that I am to be trusted with regard to my

covenant and my promises for the Ever-
lasting One of Israel does not lie or change
His mind, for He is not man to change.

Now I beg of you not be angry at
me that I have written at such length
and have thus become a burden with my
lowly writing. But please let me know
whether you liked my idea, then will
I rejoice very much, in the midst of
my pre-occupation with p general
affairs and with earning a living.
Your well-wisher
